item.title: Thomson Reuters Announces 3,200 Job Cuts Over Two Years - VOA News
item.description:
Thomson Reuters Announces 3,200 Job Cuts Over Two Years  VOA News

Financial data and news agency Thomson Reuters announced Tuesday cuts of 3,200 jobs and dozens of office closures worldwide over the next two years as part of a restructuring. Executives told an investor conference in Toronto that the staff reduction would affect 12 percent of its workforce, while the number of its offices would be reduced by 30 percent, to 133 locations. "The majority of employees have already been notified," spokesman David Crundwell told AFP. He said Thomson Reuters routinely looks to streamline its operations. "This disciplined approach sometimes includes the need to ma...

item.title: America’s next moon landing will be by private companies, not NASA - MarketWatch
item.description:
America’s next moon landing will be by private companies, not NASA  MarketWatch

ASSOCIATED PRESS By Associated Press Astronaut Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin poses next to the U.S. flag in 1969 on the moon during the Apollo 11 mission. Getty Images CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) — America’s next moon landing will be made by private companies — not NASA. NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine announced Thursday that nine U.S. companies will compete to deliver experiments to the lunar surface. The space agency will buy the service and let private industry work out the details on getting there, he said. The goal is to get small science and technology experiments to the surface of the moon as...

item.title: Investors Should Love Tech Regulation, If It Ever Happens - Forbes
item.description:
Investors Should Love Tech Regulation, If It Ever Happens  Forbes

Some investors have caught the jitters over the crescendo-like call for more tech-company regulations. They shouldn’t. Stock screens at the New York Stock Exchange. AP Photo/Mark Lennihan. Photocredit: ASSOCIATED PRESS Every data breach, or misuse of personal details by a website, leads to yet another politician calling for new legislation to rein-in big tech companies. Firms include a mass of brand-name firms such as Facebook and Twitter. None of this worry is new. You can read reports about it here, here, and here, as well as, many other places. While some of the proposals may sound burde...

item.title: In photos: Unrest at the US-Mexico border - CNN
item.description:
In photos: Unrest at the US-Mexico border  CNN

A member of Mexico's Federal Police tries to grab migrants as they attempt to cross the border into the United States on Sunday, November 25. Adrees Latif/REUTERS A migrant family from Honduras runs from tear gas that was deployed by US Border Patrol agents near the fence between Mexico and the United States. KIM KYUNG-HOON/REUTERS Mexican police run as they try to keep migrants from getting past the border crossing in Tijuana. item.title: AP cameraman shot in leg while covering Gaza protests despite wearing 'Press' on flak jacket - The Independent
item.description:
AP cameraman shot in leg while covering Gaza protests despite wearing 'Press' on flak jacket  The Independent

An Associated Press cameraman has been shot and wounded in Gaza while covering a demonstration in the north of the enclave, despite wearing protective clothing identifying him as a member of the press. Rashed Rashid, 47, a veteran employee of the American newswire, was hit in the leg on Monday during a weekly protest next to the border fence with Israel. He underwent surgery on Wednesday after suffering multiple bone fractures above the ankle. He was struck even though witnesses said he was about 600 metres from the fence and far from the protesters. Co-workers said he was also wearing a bl...

item.title: China makes u-turn on legalising the sale of rhino and tiger parts - The Independent
item.description:
China makes u-turn on legalising the sale of rhino and tiger parts  The Independent

Plans to ease a ban on the trading in tiger and rhinoceros parts have been postponed by the Chinese government. While the trade of the endangered animals was banned by the country in 1993, in October the government announced it would allow the parts to be used for medical, scientific and cultural purposes. The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) said the decision would have “devastating consequences globally” and along with other animal rights groups it raised fears that poaching and smuggling of the endangered animals could increase. Read more - New DNA insight may help save northern white rhino fro...

item.title: CNN wins temporary legal victory against Trump's ban on White House correspondent Jim Acosta - ABC News
item.description:
CNN wins temporary legal victory against Trump's ban on White House correspondent Jim Acosta  ABC News

A US judge has temporarily restored White House press credentials to CNN correspondent Jim Acosta, which were revoked following a contentious press conference with President Donald Trump, saying there should be a due process in place for limiting a journalist's access to the White House. Key points: - Trump appointee found journalist faced "irreparable harm" from White House ban - A press conference became heated as CNN correspondent asked about migrants and Russia - Media rival Fox News backed CNN, citing freedom of the press US District Judge Timothy Kelly, who is hearing CNN's lawsuit ch...

item.title: CNN sues White House over reporter's revoked credentials - ABC News
item.description:
CNN sues White House over reporter's revoked credentials  ABC News

CNN has filed a lawsuit against the Trump administration over the revocation of press credentials for White House correspondent Jim Acosta, whose questions and reporting have been a frequent target of criticism by President Donald Trump. Key points: - CNN has been a major target in Trump's barrage of criticism of the media - Trump became enraged when Acosta questioned him repeatedly at a press conference - Acosta denies White House accusations he inappropriately touched intern during verbal stoush The lawsuit was filed on Tuesday in the Washington, DC, District Court. CNN claims the revocat...

item.title: Fox News and other outlets join CNN fight over press access to White House - CNN
item.description:
Fox News and other outlets join CNN fight over press access to White House  CNN

More than a dozen news outlets -- from the Associated Press to USA Today, The Washington Post and Politico -- are filing friend-of-the-court briefs to support CNN and Jim Acosta's lawsuit against President Trump and several top aides. The list represents most of the biggest news organizations in the United States. The most notable name on the list is Fox News. In fact, Fox went further than most other media companies on Wednesday, issuing a statement that said "Secret Service passes for working White House journalists should never be weaponized." The statement came from Jay Wallace, the pre...

item.title: Rio de Janeiro mudslide leaves 10 dead after boulder crushes houses - The Independent
item.description:
Rio de Janeiro mudslide leaves 10 dead after boulder crushes houses  The Independent

A mudslide near Rio de Janeiro has left at least 10 people dead and another 11 injured, according to the Brazilian authorities. Roberto Robadey, Rio’s head of civil defence department, said Saturday’s mudslide in the nearby city of Niteroi was caused by heavy downpours. He told Brazil’s Globo TV network the fatalities and injuries happened when a large boulder rolled on top of six houses in the Boa Esperanca neighbourhood. Read more - Mudslide filmed crashing down mountain into Swiss village - More than 100 dead after floods destroy homes in Japan - North Carolina dam in danger of 'imminent...

item.title: California wildfires: Tens of thousands forced to flee as entire city ‘pretty much’ destroyed by blaze - The Independent
item.description:
California wildfires: Tens of thousands forced to flee as entire city ‘pretty much’ destroyed by blaze  The Independent

An entire Californian city has been all but destroyed as at least 14 wildfires spread across the state Paradise – population 27,000 – is said to have been left in ruins with homes, hospitals, schools and businesses all engulfed by a wall of flames. Authorities said there are unconfirmed reports of casualties and that emergency services are working desperately to rescue those left behind. - Read more Wildfire visible from space forces evacuation in California “Pretty much the community of Paradise is destroyed,” Cal Fire Captain Scott McLean told the Associated Press news agency. “It's that ...

item.title: Austria arrests former army colonel on suspicion of spying for Russia since 1990s - The Independent
item.description:
Austria arrests former army colonel on suspicion of spying for Russia since 1990s  The Independent

Austria has arrested a retired army colonel on suspicion of spying for Russia, chancellor Sebastian Kurz has said. The officer is accused of beginning to work for Russian intelligence in the 1990s and continued to maintain the relationship until 2018, Mr Kurz told a news conference. The chancellor said the case and allegations of espionage in the Netherlands, “don’t improve relations between Russia and the European Union”. - Read more Russia claims it foiled terrorist plans for World Cup attacks Earlier this year, the Netherlands expelled four Russians it suspected of planning a cyber-attac...

item.title: In Online Ruse, Fake Journalists Tried to Hack Saudi Critic - VOA News
item.description:
In Online Ruse, Fake Journalists Tried to Hack Saudi Critic  VOA News

Hackers impersonating journalists tried to intercept the communications of a prominent Saudi opposition figure in Washington, The Associated Press has found. One attempt involved the fabrication of a fake BBC secretary and an elaborate television interview request; the other involved the impersonation of slain Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi to deliver a malicious link. Media rights defenders denounced the hacking effort, which they said would make it harder for genuine reporters to do their jobs. "It's incredibly dangerous to employ this kind of tactic," said Elodie Vialle, who h...

item.title: In photos: Lion Air plane crashes off Indonesia - CNN
item.description:
In photos: Lion Air plane crashes off Indonesia  CNN

A relative of one of the crash victims tosses flower petals from an Indonesian Navy ship on Tuesday, November 6. Tatan Syuflana/AP Victims' families and colleagues react on a Navy ship as they're ferried to the crash site on November 6. Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images An Indonesian official examines a turbine engine from the plane on Sunday, November 4. BEAWIHARTA/REUTERS People in Jakarta grieve over the coffin of a relative on November 4. Ed Wray/Getty Images Indonesian Navy divers recover a flight data recorder on Thursday, November 1. Adek Berry/AFP/Getty Images Families of the victims look...

item.title: VoteCast: Voters say nation headed wrong way - The Associated Press
item.description:
The Associated Press

A majority of voters casting midterm election ballots nationally said the country is headed in the wrong direction, according to a wide-ranging survey of the American electorate. As voters cast ballots for governor, U.S. Senate and members of Congress in Tuesday's elections, AP VoteCast found that 42 percent of voters said the country is on the right track, compared with 56 percent who said the country is headed in the wrong direction. Here's a snapshot of who voted and why, based on preliminary results from AP VoteCast, an innovative nationwide survey of 116,792 voters and 22,137 nonvoters...

item.title: Four-year-girl 'gang-raped' in Indian hospital intensive care - The Independent
item.description:
Four-year-girl 'gang-raped' in Indian hospital intensive care  The Independent

Police in India are investigating claims a four-year-old girl was gang-raped by five men while she was in hospital. The girl told her grandmother that a hospital attendant and four others attacked her while she was alone on Saturday night. A local police official in the northern city of Lucknow, Mahesh Srivastava, said officers had already arrested one suspect - who was now in custody - and were searching for the others. - Read more It's taken a year, but India has finally moved into the MeToo era Detectives have also requested the hospital release its CCTV footage to them. The girl was bei...

item.title: Alleged Kroger Shooter Charged With Two Counts of Murder - The Daily Beast
item.description:
Alleged Kroger Shooter Charged With Two Counts of Murder  The Daily Beast

Carlo Allegri/Reuters, Gregory Bush, who allegedly shot and killed two black people at a Kroger grocery store near Louisville, Kentucky, was indicted on two counts of murder Wednesday. The Associated Press reports a Jefferson County grand jury also indicted Bush on “one count of criminal attempted murder and two counts of first-degree wanton endangerment.” A federal prosecutor told the AP that investigators are attempting to determine whether Bush violated any federal laws, including “potential civil rights violations” like hate crimes. Bush, a 51-year-old white man, was allegedly seen atte...

item.title: Chinese Officials Charged With Commercial Aviation ‘Espionage’ - The Daily Beast
item.description:
Chinese Officials Charged With Commercial Aviation ‘Espionage’  The Daily Beast

Max Rossi/Reuters, Chinese intelligence officers and hackers have been charged with commercial espionage, including attempts to steal information on commercial jet engines. Federal prosecutors named two officials working for the Chinese Ministry of State Security’s foreign intelligence arm and six others who allegedly conspired to “steal sensitive turbofan engine technology used in commercial aviation” between 2010 and 2015, the Associated Press reports. The hackers allegedly targeted a French aerospace company that was “developing the engines with a U.S. company” in a malware “spear phishi...

item.title: China kindergarten attack: Woman charged over stabbing of 14 school children in knife rampage - The Independent
item.description:
China kindergarten attack: Woman charged over stabbing of 14 school children in knife rampage  The Independent

A woman who police say slashed 14 children during a knife rampage at a school in the Chinese city of Chongqing has been charged with intent to commit homicide. The 39-year-old allegedly attacked the youngsters as they were walking back to class following morning exercises at Xinshiji Kindergarten. Authorities in the southwestern city have revealed only the suspect's surname, Liu. - Read more China claims Uighur Muslims grateful to be held in internment camps The attack on Friday morning caused shock across China with videos of bleeding and traumatised pupils spreading quickly across social ...

item.title: 'Traumatised the audience': Indonesian media warned over 'unethical coverage' of Lion Air crash - ABC News
item.description:
'Traumatised the audience': Indonesian media warned over 'unethical coverage' of Lion Air crash  ABC News

Indonesia's peak body for broadcasting has warned local journalists not to sensationalise the reporting of the Lion Air plane crash, in a bid to stop widespread "unethical media coverage" of major disasters. Key points: - Traumatic scenes were often displayed with melancholic music to dramatise the event - Eliciting emotion from vulnerable interviewees is a common practice in Indonesia - Some say it's a response to being pressured to file stories when there are no updates The Indonesian Broadcasting Commission (KPI) made the plea a day after Flight JT610 crashed into the Java Sea with 189 p...

item.title: Whitey Bulger: Infamous Boston gangster killed in West Virginia jail aged 89 - The Independent
item.description:
Whitey Bulger: Infamous Boston gangster killed in West Virginia jail aged 89  The Independent

James ‘Whitey’ Bulger, a notorious gangster whose life and crimes in Boston became the focus of several major films, has died in jail. The 89-year-old was known as the leader of South Boston’s Winter Hill Gang, a violent Massachusetts group that was famous throughout the city during his more than two decades as a gangster. Mr Bulger ​was serving a life sentence after being convicted in 2013 of a litany of crimes, including participating in 11 murders. He was one of the FBI’s most wanted fugitives for 16 years until his 2011 arrest in Santa Monica, California. - Read more Cesar Sayoc arrest:...

item.title: Pittsburgh shooter suspect Robert Bowers appears in court in wheelchair as prosecutor seek death penalty - The Independent
item.description:
Pittsburgh shooter suspect Robert Bowers appears in court in wheelchair as prosecutor seek death penalty  The Independent

The man accused of shooting dead 11 people inside a Pittsburgh synagogue, an incident described by prosecutors as “an horrific act of violence”, has appeared in court in a wheelchair where 29 charges were read to him aloud. Robert Bowers, 46, who is said to have written a number of racist and antisemitic social media posts before carrying out the rampage, was wheeled into the court in handcuffs and was asked if he understood the charges levelled against him. CNN said that Mr Bowers, dressed in a blue shirt, briefly had the handcuffs removed, so he could sign legal documents. The judge then ...

item.title: White House invites Putin to Washington 'in early 2019', John Bolton announces - The Independent
item.description:
White House invites Putin to Washington 'in early 2019', John Bolton announces  The Independent

Russian President Vladimir Putin has been invited to visit Washington in “early 2019,” Donald Trump’s National Security Advisor John Bolton has announced. Mr Bolton spoke at a press conference in Georgia on Friday morning. He said that scheduling for the trip had yet to be worked out but Mr Putin would be invited “after the first of the year.” “We have invited President Putin to Washington after the first of the year for, basically, a full day of consultations,” Mr Bolton said, days after meeting the Russian president in Moscow. “What the scheduling of that is we don’t quite know yet.” - Re...

item.title: Alt-right leader's wife files for divorce, accusing him of abuse - ABC News
item.description:
Alt-right leader's wife files for divorce, accusing him of abuse  ABC News

The wife of US white nationalist leader Richard Spencer has accused him of physically, verbally and emotionally abusing her throughout their eight-year marriage. Key points: - Nina Koupriianova accused Mr Spencer of dragging her off her bed and down a flight of stairs in 2011 - She also accused him of an attacking and bruising her in 2014 when she was four months pregnant - Mr Spencer told Associated Press he is "not an abusive person" and his wife was "never in a dangerous situation" In a court filing for the couple's divorce proceedings in Montana, Nina Koupriianova said Mr Spencer once l...

item.title: Former Justice Sandra Day O'Connor diagnosed with 'beginning stages of dementia' - The Independent
item.description:
Former Justice Sandra Day O'Connor diagnosed with 'beginning stages of dementia'  The Independent

Sandra Day O’Connor, the first woman to serve on the US Supreme Court, has been diagnosed with the "beginning stages of dementia," the retired justice revealed in a letter Tuesday. The 88-year-old former justice said she "probably" has Alzheimer's disease, a form of dementia that develops over time and causes issues with memory and behaviour. "I will continue living in Phoenix, Arizona surrounded by dear friends and family," she wrote. "While the final chapter of my life with dementia may be trying, nothing has diminished my gratitude and deep appreciation for the countless blessings of my ...

item.title: Kansas Man Guilty In Death Of Boy Found Encased In Concrete - HuffPost
item.description:
Kansas Man Guilty In Death Of Boy Found Encased In Concrete  HuffPost

A Kansas man has been found guilty of first-degree murder in the death of a 3-year-old boy whose body was found encased in concrete four months after his death. Stephen Bodine, 41, of Wichita, was convicted by a jury Wednesday in the May 2017 death of Evan Brewer, the son of his girlfriend, Miranda Miller. In addition, Bodine was also found guilty of child abuse, aggravated child endangerment and two counts of kidnapping, according to The Associated Press. Bodine will be sentenced Dec. 17. The murder conviction alone carries a potential sentence of life in prison with parole eligibility aft...

item.title: CNN bomb threat: Offices evacuated in New York over reports of 'explosive device' - The Independent
item.description:
CNN bomb threat: Offices evacuated in New York over reports of 'explosive device'  The Independent

CNN's offices in New York have been evacuated over reports of a potential explosive device. The device was sent to the Time Warner Center and discovered in the building's mail room. It comes after the US Secret Service said agents had intercepted suspicious packages addressed to former president Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. - Read more Follow live updates as 'bombs' sent to Clintons and Obama homes The device at the Time Warner Center was "constructed with a pipe and wires" CNN reported, quoting an unnamed police source. It is being treated as a real device Video posted on social media...

item.title: Suspicious device sent to Time Warner Center - CNN
item.description:
Suspicious device sent to Time Warner Center  CNN

Police stand guard on a closed street after a suspicious package was discovered at the Time Warner Center in New York on Wednesday, October 24. CNN's New York bureau in the building was evacuated. Justin Lane/EPA/REX/Shutterstock The suspicious package was removed from CNN's offices in Manhattan and sent to a New York police facility in the Bronx, officials said. Shannon Stapleton/Reuters A Time Warner Center mailroom employee flagged the package to security but did not open it, according to a source with direct knowledge. Security called authorities, who opened the package. Obtained by CNN...

item.title: George Soros: Device found at billionaire's home was bomb, police reveal - The Independent
item.description:
George Soros: Device found at billionaire's home was bomb, police reveal  The Independent

A device found at billionaire George Soros's New York home was a bomb with explosive powder, a law enforcement official has revealed. Speaking on condition of anonymity, the official said the object found outside Mr Soros's property in Westchester County on Tuesday, contained all the components of a bomb, including explosive powder. The official told the Associated Press investigators were reviewing surveillance video to determine whether the package had been sent through the mail. - Read more Explosive device found at philanthropist George Soros’ home “The components were there for an expl...

item.title: Snapchat's Scripted Show Approach to Lure Black Teens - Forbes
item.description:
Snapchat's Scripted Show Approach to Lure Black Teens  Forbes

Jennea Bivens, left, talks with her 13-year-old daughter, Ayrial Miller, about the contacts in her Snapchat social media account while sitting on the couch in their Chicago apartment, Monday, June 18, 2018. Bivens uses a monitoring app to track and limit her daughter’s phone use, but says there’s no replacement for a face-to-face conversation, especially about social media. Tracking her daughter’s social media, she says, can be “a full-time job.” (AP Photo/Martha Irvine) Snap announced 12 new “Snap Originals” scripted shows in effort to regain its popularity with the very coveted but fickle...

item.title: Mega Millions jackpot reaches $1bn and could grow even bigger - The Independent
item.description:
Mega Millions jackpot reaches $1bn and could grow even bigger  The Independent

This week's Mega Millions lottery has reached the highest jackpot in the game’s history—$1 billion (£765m). The winning numbers will be selected on Friday night. Each $2 ticket has a one in 302.5 million chance of winning. This is the biggest jackpot that the Mega Millions has ever had. However, it is only the second biggest lottery prize in U.S. history. The 2016 Powerball jackpot was $1.56bn. If no one wins on Friday, the Mega Millions lottery pot will go up to $1.6bn on Tuesday. - Read more Mega Millions lottery tops $900m in America Kirit Prajapati, who sells lottery tickets at a Carlto...

item.title: ‘Guilty until proven innocent’: Trump compares missing Saudi journalist case to Kavanaugh accusations - The Independent
item.description:
‘Guilty until proven innocent’: Trump compares missing Saudi journalist case to Kavanaugh accusations  The Independent

President Trump has criticised the global uproar over Saudi Arabia's suspected role in the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, likening the situation to the sexual assault allegations levelled against Supreme Court justice Brett Kavanaugh during his confirmation hearing. "Here we go again with you're guilty until proven innocent," Trump told the Associated Press in an interview. "I don't like that. We just went through that with Justice Kavanaugh and he was innocent all the way as far as I'm concerned." Read more - Inside the kingdom, Saudis rattled by handling of Jamal Khashoggi c...

item.title: Trump: I'm not to blame if GOP loses House - CNN
item.description:
Trump: I'm not to blame if GOP loses House  CNN

Trump told the AP that he will not accept responsibility if Republicans lose their majority in the House. ©2018 Cable News Network, Inc. A WarnerMedia Company. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: AP: Trump compares Saudi, Kavanaugh accusations - CNN
item.description:
AP: Trump compares Saudi, Kavanaugh accusations  CNN

According to the Associated Press, President Trump compared the accusations against Saudi Arabia to the allegations against Brett Kavanaugh. ©2018 Cable News Network, Inc. A WarnerMedia Company. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: In pictures: Hurricane Michael's trail of destruction - CNN
item.description:
In pictures: Hurricane Michael's trail of destruction  CNN

President Donald Trump, first lady Melania Trump and Florida Gov. Rick Scott tour a Lynn Haven, Florida, neighborhood that was affected by Hurricane Michael. Evan Vucci/AP Lisa Patrick is overcome with emotion as she visits the remains of her home in Mexico Beach, Florida, on Monday, October 15. item.title: Meet President Trump, the White House's top spokesperson - CNN
item.description:
Meet President Trump, the White House's top spokesperson  CNN

The White House's top spokesman, also known as President Trump, says "we're communicating very well" now that he is giving interviews and talking to the press almost every day. Trump has truly become his own spokesperson -- holding semi-regular Q&A's with reporters at the same time the press shop's daily briefing has been shelved. On Tuesday he went from a taping for the Fox Business Network to an interview with The Associated Press. On Wednesday he was back on Fox Business for another interview. He complained to Fox's Stuart Varney about the AP, saying the quotes were "perfect" but one of ...

item.title: Midterms 2018: Republicans shift resources from House candidates 'too far gone' as Trump contemplates defeat - The Independent
item.description:
Midterms 2018: Republicans shift resources from House candidates 'too far gone' as Trump contemplates defeat  The Independent

Republicans are shifting limited resources away from candidates they fear are “far too gone”, as they face a wave of Democrat enthusiasm and fund-raising that seems set to give them control of the House of Representatives. With barely three weeks before the midterm elections on November 6, officials and aides are trading in recriminations and finger-pointing, as they appear to be faced by a “blue wave”. At the same time, the White House is reaching out to Democrats on Capitol Hill, in preparation for having to deal with them after the autumn ballot. "We're starting to hone in on what are th...

item.title: Donald Trump says Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi could have been murdered by 'rogue killers' - The Independent
item.description:
Donald Trump says Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi could have been murdered by 'rogue killers'  The Independent

Donald Trump has suggested that missing Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi could have been murdered by "rogue killers" after speaking to the kingdom's ruler, who denied having any involvement in the incident. In comments that drew immediate criticism for his apparent unquestioning acceptance of the Saudi denial, Mr Trump said he was dispatching Mike Pompeo to meet King Salman in Saudi Arabia, a major purchaser of US arms. “It sounded to me that maybe this could have been rogue killers,” Mr Trump said about his call to king. “His denial to me could not be stronger.” - Read more Turkish authori...

item.title: Trump to AP: Saudi Arabia criticism makes the nation 'guilty until proven innocent' - CNN
item.description:
Trump to AP: Saudi Arabia criticism makes the nation 'guilty until proven innocent'  CNN

President Donald Trump defended Saudi Arabia in an interview Tuesday, suggesting the wave of criticism the Middle Eastern kingdom has received over a missing Saudi journalist is premature. "Here we go again with you know you're guilty until proven innocent," Trump told The Associated Press in an interview at the White House. The AP's report said Trump compared the accusations against Saudi Arabia, which stands accusing of killing Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi, to sexual assault allegations against recently confirmed Justice Brett Kavanaugh. "I don't like that," Trump said. "We j...
